items.title: The Rise of the Seljuk Turks: From Steppe Raiders to Medieval Empire
items.author: Epic History
items.content:
<article>The Rise of the Seljuk Turks chronicles how a Turko-Persian frontier confederation grew into one of the medieval world‚Äôs most influential empires. Emerging from the steppes of Central Asia, the Seljuks united inner-city Persia with Turkic cavalry might, transforming political and cultural landscapes across Iran, Iraq, and Anatolia. Under Tughril Beg, they consolidated power in the early 11th century, capturing Ray and routing rival dynasties to establish the Great Seljuk state. The empire expanded under Alp Arslan, whose victory at Manzikert in 1071 shattered Byzantium‚Äôs frontier and opened Anatolia to Turkish settlement, setting the stage for the Turkic-ruled Sultanate of Rum. Malik Shah I presided over a prosperous era, supported by the brilliant vizier Nizam al-Mulk and a thriving network of madrasas that fused Sunni scholarship with Persian administrative sophistication. The Seljuks pioneered a centralized yet adaptive governance model, blending military prowess with a sophisticated bureaucratic system that influenced governance across the region for centuries. As they defended eastern borders against rival powers and fostered a rich cultural milieu, their rise also created the conditions for Crusades to enter the Levant. This video unpacks the key figures, battles, and institutions that defined the Seljuk ascent, and traces their enduring legacy in Anatolia, Iran, and the broader Islamic world. If you love medieval history and the fusion of Turkic and Persian influences, subscribe for more on the rise and legacy of the Seljuk Turks. 

#SeljukEmpire #SeljukTurks #MedievalHistory #Manzikert #Crusades #IslamicHistory #TurkishHistory #epichistory</article>

items.title: Help for single parents - Can work and family life work better? | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>For many single parents, everyday life can be a challenge. But a number of projects offer assistance and encouragement. Affordable housing, social networking, and childcare services are designed to ease the burden.

Single parents in Europe can increasingly rely on help and support from people, associations, and institutions to help them balance raising children with work, financial issues, and mental overload. 

"A secure, affordable living situation - that's such a key issue in the lives of single parents,‚Äù says Sarah Zeller. A few years ago, she found herself confronting this issue when, along with another friend and her child, she decided to set up a shared apartment for the two single parent families. But they searched in vain for an affordable apartment with enough space. 

This predicament gave rise to an innovative approach. In 2015, the German native founded the non-profit association JUNO in Vienna. Working with property developers, the association plans and develops compact and affordable apartments for single parents. With her idea, the founder has now helped over 160 families find a suitable apartment. 

The Belgian region of Wallonia has set itself the goal of strengthening the social position of single parents. Amandine Dedoncker is a social worker involved in the "Relais Familles Mono‚Äù program, creating services tailored to the needs of single parents. The government program enables single parents to learn practical skills, meet other mothers or fathers, and be part of a community. As a population group particularly affected by loneliness, this is extremely important for single parents‚Äò mental health. 
When other families have free time, on Saturdays Bianka Baumann is at work: in a supermarket in Rostock. The single mother and sales assistant works weekends. But who looks after her son Linus, during a time when most daycare centers are closed? An innovative daycare center here makes her weekend work possible by offering overnight care for parents who work night shifts. 
All of this is financed by the state of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania. A model that supports single parents - and makes it possible to truly balance work and family life.

items.title: Queen Alexandra - The Wife Who Invited Her Husband‚Äôs Mistress to His Deathbed Documentary
items.author: The People Profiles
items.content:
<article>Queen Alexandra of Denmark was the most beloved woman in the British Empire, but behind her radiant smile lay a life of hidden tragedy and physical disability. This documentary explores the remarkable life of the woman who served as the longest-serving Princess of Wales and eventually Queen Consort to King Edward VII.

While the Edwardian era is often remembered for its lavish parties and the "Marlborough House Set," Alexandra‚Äôs private reality was defined by her battle with progressive deafness and the "Alexandra Limp"‚Äîa physical disability caused by rheumatic fever that, bizarrely, became a viral fashion trend among the Victorian elite. From her "rags-to-riches" journey as a Danish princess to her complicated marriage to a "Playboy King," we reveal how she navigated his high-profile mistresses (including Alice Keppel) and the strict demands of Queen Victoria.

items.title: Toxic colonialism - Secret chemical warfare in Algeria | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>France secretly used chemical weapons against independence fighters during the Algerian War. Newly evaluated archive material, eyewitnesses, and experts document the extent, background, and consequences of this warfare.

A little-known chapter of colonial violence: The French army secretly used chemical weapons against independence fighters during the Algerian War (1954-1962). Maps, documents, and eyewitness accounts from French and Algerian veterans document the dimension of this warfare, as well as the human suffering it caused. 

Interviews with experts on nuclear, biological, and chemical weapons explain how military and political decision-makers organized these secret attacks. In addition to the torture and displacement of entire population groups, the use of chemical weapons constituted a huge breach of France's international obligations. Obligations France deliberately disregarded during its colonial war. 

Step by step, the film reveals the impact of this warfare on Algeria‚Äôs land and people. The film illuminates both the historical events, and their current relevance.

#documentary #dwdocumentary #dwdocs #frenchcolonialism #colonialism #algeria

items.title: Libertarians in search of utopia | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>Liberland is a country that promises voluntary taxes and a lean state: A libertarian utopia that‚Äôs attracting like-minded people around the world. The only problem for its supporters? It doesn't officially exist. 

After the Yugoslav Wars, the border between Serbia and Croatia along the Danube River remained unresolved. Vit Jedliƒçka, a former politician from the Czech Republic, saw an opportunity. In 2015, he declared the ‚ÄúFree Republic of Liberland‚Äù on a 7-square-kilometer piece of land. 

The Liberland experiment may seem like an oddity, but it also raises serious questions: Cryptocurrencies and decentralized networks are undermining traditional national borders, and radical market ideas are gaining influence. Parallel structures are emerging. Critics see them as a threat to democracy, whereas supporters see an opening. 

Watch the full-length documentary ‚ÄúLiberland: Crypto paradise or libertarian illusion?‚Äù on our channel.

items.title: How Jeffrey Epstein fooled America | Today, Explained
items.author: Vox
items.content:
<article>Jeffrey Epstein remained a thriving member of the elite for decades, even when everyone seemed to know what he was doing. His sphere of influence included top political officials, CEOs, corporate executives, finance managers, and even a member of the British royal family. How did he manage it? It turns out it was by establishing an elaborate network of influence and access that went well beyond the norms and expectations of the rich and famous.

What were the tipping points that nearly brought Epstein to justice in the 14 years before his first conviction and his final 2019 arrest? What were the structures and systems that failed to stop him from abusing and exploiting young women and girls in those 14 years? In this episode, we tick through the guest lists and institutions that continued to profit from relationships with Jeffrey Epstein ‚Äî and which helped him remain free, in turn.

We will also talk about many of the conspiracy theories that have popped up since the latest tranche of Epstein documents came out. Was Epstein a national security asset? Did he actually kill himself?

Independent journalist Tara Palmeri, author of the Red Letter Substack and host of The Tara Palmeri Show, argues that conspiracies are important to help the public understand the extent and scope of the Epstein scandal ‚Äî since for so long, so much about the story was covered up. We‚Äôll make sense of which conspiracies have validity and which are tinfoil hat material, in this interview with a journalist who has long advocated for and written about the Epstein survivors.

items.title: What was immigration like before ICE?
items.author: Vox
items.content:
<article>In the history section on ICE‚Äôs website, one line reads: ‚ÄúDespite U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement's relatively young age, its functional history predates the modern birth of the agency by more than 200 years.‚Äù That phrasing of ‚Äúfunctional history‚Äù stands out. We know that ICE was created in 2003. So what exactly do they mean by that? To unpack this claim, Vox producer Nate Krieger examines the history of immigration enforcement in the US. 

The story of American immigration is one of gradual change. Over time, the role of the immigration services slowly changed, morphing from an agency that managed labor and benefits to one that saw itself as law enforcement, with a focus on national security. 

And with that shift came a growth in capacity. The first federal immigration agency was created in 1891 with a total staff of 4 people. Today, with ICE, that number is over 22,000.

So how did immigration restrictions and enforcement change over the span of American history? By examining the centuries of events that culminated in the creation of ICE, we can begin to understand the context that created this modern agency. 

Sources and further reading: 

For more context, images, and written accounts of Ellis Island, see this page on the National Park Service‚Äôs website: https://www.nps.gov/elis/learn/historyculture/index.htm

For this story, Nate Krieger focused on the history leading up to 2003 and the creation of ICE, so the piece does not delve into more recent developments. But detailed information and data on deportation in President Donald Trump‚Äôs second term can be found here: https://www.americanimmigrationcouncil.org/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/immigration-detention-report.pdf and https://deportationdata.org/analysis/immigration-enforcement-first-nine-months-trump

And more information on ICE‚Äôs arrests in the interior, which are a relatively recent phenomenon, can be found here: https://www.migrationpolicy.org/content/ice-arrests-deportations-interior

This piece only touched on Japanese incarceration during the Second World War. For more information ‚Äî and first-hand accounts ‚Äî about this important subject, Densho is a fantastic resource: https://ddr.densho.org/

"Immigration: How the Past Shapes The Present" by the sociologist Nancy Foner, who was interviewed for this piece, is a comprehensive look into why the past is critical to understanding modern immigration: https://www.politybooks.com/bookdetail?book_slug=immigration-how-the-past-shapes-the-present--9781509557912

items.author: Real Time History
items.content:
<article>Get Nebula with 50% off annual subscription with my link: https://go.nebula.tv/realtimehistory
Watch our new series History's Most Daring Raids: https://nebula.tv/videos/realtimehistory-cabanatuan-the-great-us-ranger-raid-to-save-500-pows-historys-most-daring-raids-episode-1 

After the defeat in the 1st Sino-Japanese War, the Qing Dynasty is under pressure: Some are calling for domestic reforms and ousting Western influence, while the Great Powers want to further open up China for their businesses. This is a remastered version of our Ice Age video from July 2025. We've made a few changes, but apologies if you've watched the video already! 

In this video, we‚Äôre travelling back to Earth's frozen past, to discover what our planet was like during the Ice Age. items.title: saut√© chicken with prawn butter sauce| flavored Butters ep1
items.author: French Cooking Academy
items.content:
<article>Get our free eBook: ‚ñ∫https://french-cooking-academy.myflodesk.com/hb6z0zrnq5
Want to join my cooking community  ‚û°Ô∏è https://www.thefrenchcookingacademy.com/fcaclub

How to make prawn compound butter and use it to cook Poulet Sacha Guitry ‚Äî a classic French chicken dish with cream, Madeira and morels.

This recipe was originally created by Fernand Point, the legendary chef behind La Pyramide restaurant in Vienne, France. He dedicated it to Sacha Guitry, the famous French actor and screenwriter, who loved crayfish butter. I've adapted it for the home kitchen using cooked prawns.
A compound butter is a flavoured butter made by blending softened butter with other ingredients ‚Äî in this case, cooked prawns with their shells and coral. What makes this dish unique is that the compound butter is not just served on top. It is used as a cooking fat, and then whisked into the sauce at the end to give it a rich, silky shellfish finish.

In this video you will learn how to:

Make a prawn compound butter from scratch using a stick blender
Cook chicken breasts √† blanc (with minimal colour)
White-cook mushrooms in butter, lemon and water
Build a French cream sauce using Madeira wine
Use compound butter as a sauce thickener and enrichment
Prepare and saut√© dried morels

This is Part 1 of a 3-part series on compound butters in French cooking.

items.title: The Universe Is Racing Apart. We May Finally Know Why.
items.author: PBS Space Time
items.content:
<article>Get a special 35% discount on an annual digital subscription to The Economist at https://www.economist.com/PBS

We've known that the universe is expanding since 1929, and that its expansion is accelerating since 1998. The culprit behind the acceleration is unknown, so we live with a stand-in term "dark energy". Our modern cosmological model assumes that dark energy has a constant density--always the same amount of the outward-shoving stuff per volume. But there's recent evidence to the contrary--which may be why our primary efforts to measure the expansion rate of the universe disagree with each other.

items.title: Tudor Expert Reacts To ‚ÄòMary Queen of Scots' Movie
items.author: History Hit
items.content:
<article>Watch Tudor Historian react to Mary Queen of Scots Movie. 

Dr. Paul examines key moments from the 2018 film Mary Queen of Scots, directed by Josie Rourke, starring Saoirse Ronan as Mary and Margot Robbie as Elizabeth I. She analyses the historical accuracy of pivotal scenes, from Mary‚Äôs return to Scotland after her time in France to her turbulent marriages, political struggles with the Scottish nobility, and her fraught rivalry with Elizabeth.

0:00 The Young Henry VIII & Catherine of Aragon ('The Spanish Princess')
12:24 The Anne Boleyn Affair ('The Other Boleyn Girl')
27:18 A Son & A New Wife: Jane Seymour & Anne of Cleves ('Wolf Hall')
42:54 The Teenage Queen: Katherine Howard ('The Tudors')
54:11 Jude Law & The Final Years with Katherine Parr ('Firebrand')
1:08:16 Historian's Final Verdict on Henry VIII Portrayals

Throughout the video, Dr. Paul critiques the casting and character portrayals, discussing how Ronan and Robbie capture the intelligence, vulnerability, and political acumen of two powerful Renaissance queens. She explores the realities behind the drama, including Mary‚Äôs marriage to Lord Darnley, the murder of David Rizzio, the scandal surrounding the Earl of Bothwell, her forced abdication, and eventual imprisonment in England. 

The review culminates in a close look at Mary‚Äôs trial and execution, separating cinematic invention from the complex historical record surrounding one of the most compelling monarchs of the sixteenth century.

items.title: The Rise of Napoleon Bonaparte: From Corsican Soldier to European Emperor
items.author: Epic History
items.content: <article>From a modest Corsican artillery officer to the master of Europe, Napoleon Bonaparte‚Äôs ascent after the French Revolution reshaped maps, laws, and destinies. This concise history traces how his military genius, political skill, and relentless reform propelled him from lieutenant to consul and finally emperor, setting the stage for nearly two decades of continental domination. We tour the pivotal moves‚Äîthe coup of 18 Brumaire, the centralization of authority, and the Napoleonic Code that codified revolutionary ideals into everyday law. We examine how campaigns across Italy, Austria, and Egypt demonstrated both daring strategy and fragile supply networks, while battles such as Ulm, Austerlitz, and Jena showcased a genius for rapid, decisive action that forced coalitions to adapt or collapse. The narrative then turns to the continental system, designed to cripple Britain and redraw European trade, and to the political architecture that forged client states, reshaped governance, and sparked nationalist currents that outlived the Emperor himself. The rise‚Äôs zenith gave way to a brutal winter in Russia, a string of defeats, and a dramatic exile that ended an era, only for legacies‚Äîlegal reforms, administrative efficiency, and a lasting, controversial vision of European order‚Äîto echo long after Napoleon‚Äôs fall. This video explains the complex causes and consequences of European domination under Napoleon, offering clear context for students and history lovers alike, while linking events to the broader currents of the era. If you enjoy sharp, accessible history, subscribe for more concise historical explorations. Subscribe for more concise historical explorations.</article>

items.title: What does dying feel like? | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>What does dying feel like? What is it like to stand on the threshold of death ‚Äî and turn back? Three young women talk about their near-death experiences and how these moments changed their lives.

"I used to be extremely afraid of death. But ever since my near-death experience, that's no longer the case," says model Chanel Silberberg, who became famous through the German reality TV show "Germany's Next Topmodel." She nearly died at the age of 11 from complications related to a chronic illness. The experience fundamentally shaped her.
Why do near-death experiences have such a lasting impact? This documentary shares the dramatic and inspiring stories of three young women who stood on the brink between life and death and returned with a completely new life perspective. Their background stories are vastly different: Laethisia Schimek is a competitive athlete; L√©a Winzenried is a dance therapist; and Chanel Silberberg is a model and influencer. What all three have in common is an awareness of the finiteness of life, and a drive to experience it to the fullest.

DESCRIPTION
Matt Godbolt interviews Frances Buontempo about her book "Learn C++ by Example", a practical guide aimed at helping programmers relearn modern C++ features introduced since C++11. Frances shares her unique teaching philosophy, which emphasizes self-contained, playable examples like simple games that make complex concepts accessible and memorable.

Drawing on her background in mathematics and her father's work in teacher education, she explains how her approach‚Äîexemplified by her famous "X Out of a Y Paper Bag" series of talks‚Äîuses humor and practical scenarios to help learners understand challenging topics like coroutines, the spaceship operator, and the "almost always auto" style. The discussion touches on the evolution of C++, the upcoming reflection features in C++26, and Fran's current project: writing an introductory C++ book for complete beginners, despite finding concepts like "constant variable" challenging to explain even as an experienced author.

items.title: Jiang Qing - The Madness of Madame Mao Documentary
items.author: The People Profiles
items.content:
<article>She was Mao Zedong‚Äôs fourth wife, a failed Shanghai actress, and the most feared woman in modern history. In this documentary, we unmask Jiang Qing, the woman who rose from the fringes of the communist movement to become the de-facto dictator of the Cultural Revolution. While Chairman Mao held the title, it was Jiang Qing who held the leash‚Äîorchestrating a decade of chaos, purges, and cultural erasure that left an indelible scar on China.

How did a struggling film star become the "White-Boned Demon" of the Politburo? We explore her radical rise to power, her ruthless control over the Gang of Four, and her dramatic downfall in the most famous show trial in Chinese history.

items.title: The raw materials dilemma: Europe, China, and the Green Deal | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>The "Green Deal‚Äù is Europe's recipe for economic growth and climate protection. But green technologies require critical raw materials, which often come from China. Is more mining in Europe a viable solution?

Europe wants to encourage economic growth, while also saving our planet from climate collapse. The name of the plan to do this is the "Green Deal.‚Äù Under the Green Deal, electric cars are supposed to replace combustion engines, and renewable energies will be used instead of coal, oil, and gas. 
But green technologies require many critical raw materials, like lithium and rare earths. But these raw materials are rarely mined in Europe anymore. Currently, they come from faraway places like Africa, South America, Russia, and above all, China.
 
The ensuing dependence poses a risk to the European economy. Politicians and industry leaders now want to bring some mining back to Europe. They promise green, sustainable mines with as little impact on the environment as possible. But in places where these types of mines are being built, people are fighting back. They fear that their regions will be sacrificed for the energy transition.


#documentary #dwdocumentary #dwdocs #rawmaterials 
______

DW Documentary gives you knowledge beyond the headlines. Watch top documentaries from German broadcasters and international production companies. Meet intriguing people, travel to distant lands, get a look behind the complexities of daily life and build a deeper understanding of current affairs and global events. items.title: A Forgotten WW1 Machine Gun: The Bergmann MG 15nA with Curatorial Assistant Joe Ford
items.author: Royal Armouries
items.content:
<article>In this episode of What Is This Weapon?, Joe Ford takes a detailed look at the Bergmann MG 15nA, a late First World War German light machine gun.

Developed from Bergmann‚Äôs earlier heavy and medium machine gun designs, the LMG 15 evolved from the 1910 and 1915 models to meet urgent wartime demand for portable infantry machine guns.

ABSTRACT
As AI agents become increasingly integrated into software development, we find ourselves facing questions about how our programming languages and tools should evolve, in order to make coding agents and ourselves more productive.

items.title: The Highs & Lows of ‚ÄúThe Hugo Ch√°vez Show‚Äù (full documentary) | FRONTLINE (PBS)
items.author: FRONTLINE PBS | Official
items.content:
<article>A 90-minute documentary examining Venezuela‚Äôs controversial and outspoken late former president Hugo Ch√°vez and the revolution he claimed was turning his country into an anti-capitalist beacon for Latin America and the world. (Aired 2008) 

This journalism is made possible by viewers like you. Donate to FRONTLINE now: https://bit.ly/47DFzCb

And support your local PBS station here: https://www.pbs.org/donate

In ‚ÄúThe Hugo Ch√°vez Show,‚Äù FRONTLINE traveled to Venezuela to offer an illuminating portrait of the country‚Äôs  then-president, Hugo Ch√°vez. Through interviews with former government officials, Ch√°vez associates and critics, and ordinary Venezuelans, FRONTLINE chronicled how Ch√°vez ascended to power,  how he became a dominant figure in recent Latin American history, and how he used broadcast media to spread the ‚Äú21st-century socialism‚Äù he espoused.

Memorably, the documentary introduced U.S. viewers to ‚ÄúAl√≥ Presidente‚Äù ‚Äî or ‚ÄúHello, President‚Äù ‚Äî a weekly televised show that often ran five to eight hours and featured Ch√°vez speaking directly to the people, explaining government policy and mixing in a smattering of songs, poetry and whatever else struck his fancy. Beyond being a venue for Ch√°vez‚Äôs personality, the program served as a weekly window into the Venezuelan government, with Ch√°vez often announcing major policy decisions on live television.

With Venezuela in the headlines following the U.S. government‚Äôs capture of Nicol√°s Maduro, who was Ch√°vez‚Äôs protege and successor, ‚ÄúThe Hugo Ch√°vez Show‚Äù offers important context on Venezuela‚Äôs political history and the accomplishments, failures, appeal and repression of the Ch√°vez era.

Praise for ‚ÄúThe Hugo Chavez Show‚Äù:
‚ÄúThis portrait transcends news events.‚Äù ‚Äì David Montgomery, The Washington Post
‚ÄúAn even-handed, unillusioned view of a highly perplexing figure.‚Äù ‚Äì Mark Feeney, The Boston Globe
‚ÄúA fascinatingly revealing documentary.‚Äù ‚Äì Kate Taylor, The Globe and Mail 

‚ÄúThe Hugo Ch√°vez Show‚Äù is a FRONTLINE co-production with Ofra Bikel Productions. The producer, writer and director was Ofra Bikel. 

Explore additional reporting on ‚ÄúThe Hugo Ch√°vez Show‚Äù on our website:
https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/documentary/hugochavez/

items.title: Asbestos is a bigger problem than we thought
items.author: Veritasium
items.content:
<article>How asbestos ended up everywhere, and why we‚Äôre still using it today. Sponsored by Ground News - Go to https://ground.news/Ve for 40% off the unlimited Vantage plan, to catch how major public health stories are covered across the political spectrum and spot media bias for yourself.

If you‚Äôre looking for a molecular modelling kit, try Snatoms, a kit I invented where the atoms snap together magnetically - https://ve42.co/SnatomsV 

Sign up for the Veritasium newsletter for weekly science updates - https://ve42.co/Newsletter 

‚ñÄ‚ñÄ‚ñÄ

items.title: The deadly route to Europe: Exploited by smugglers, human traffickers and warlords | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>Thousands of people from Africa attempt to reach Europe via the Mediterranean. The EU is disrupting these migration routes and outsourcing its border control responsibilities to countries in the Sahara and Sahel regions.

Christian and David try not to fall off the back of the pick-up. The vehicle is being driven at breakneck speed through the desert by smugglers. Like hundreds of thousands of people before them, the two Nigerians are traveling from West Africa to the Libyan Mediterranean coast. They‚Äôre hoping to reach Europe and the promise of a better life.

In a bid to stem irregular migration, the European Union is ramping up spending on migration, asylum and border management to tens of billions of euros. Some of the money funds migration partnerships with African countries. The aim is to halt people well before they reach Europe‚Äôs external borders. Local security forces are under orders to stop migrants in the desert, effectively making the Sahara a key arena in Europe‚Äôs border policy. But many of these desert regions have limited governance. Smuggling networks, human traffickers and armed groups operate there with general impunity.

The documentary joins migrants on the most dangerous leg of their trip: traversing the Sahara. An investigative journey on a migration route that reveals the full reach of Europe‚Äôs border policies - and the price paid by those desperate to reach the continent.
Only those who‚Äôve survived the traffickers and torturers, who haven‚Äôt been imprisoned and deported, reach the Mediterranean. And crossing the sea brings a whole set of new dangers.


#documentary #dwdocumentary #dwdocs #europe #migration 
______

DW Documentary gives you knowledge beyond the headlines. Watch top documentaries from German broadcasters and international production companies. items.title: The biggest myths about Neanderthals - Bruce Hardy
items.author: TED-Ed
items.content:
<article>Dig into the surprisingly complex lives of Neanderthals, and explore theories on what happened to our evolutionary cousins.

--

In 1856, quarriers working in Germany‚Äôs Neander Valley discovered several mysterious fossils. The remains changed hands until being identified as the skullcap and femur bones of something ancient and human, but not quite us. It soon became clear they belonged to an extinct human species‚Äî the first ever known to science: Neanderthals. Bruce Hardy explores what happened to our evolutionary cousins.

Lesson by Bruce Hardy, directed by Daniel Harisberger, Team Tumult.

items.title: Great Art Explained Talk: Bangalore 8 Feb 2026
items.author: Great Art Explained
items.content:
<article>¬©Bangalore International Centre

A different kind of video.

In this recording of a talk I recently gave, I first of all discuss my journey to YouTube (first 15mins), and then I talk about how art can (and should) be seen in so many different ways, and all are relevant.  

I never set out to become a "YouTuber". I simply wanted to make art history accessible, stumbling into success with over two million subscribers along the way. And now, a book! 

‚ÄúIn a world of noise and distraction,‚Äù I say in my book, ‚Äúgreat art slows us down. It demands attention, reflection, and interpretation. It doesn‚Äôt exist to give us easy answers‚Äîbut it does give us better questions.‚Äù

In this illustrated talk, I bring my signature storytelling and striking visuals to explore celebrated artworks not as distant masterpieces, but as creations shaped by real people, real pressures, real ambitions. Through visual analysis, historical context, and human stories, I reveal how art intersects with power, class, money, religion, politics, and everyday life. No academic jargon. No dense theory. Just essential questions: Why was this made? What did it mean then? Why does it matter now?

Throughout the talk, I encourage and guide the audience to slow down and really look. Details often missed in galleries are brought into focus, helping viewers understand how artists guide the eye, create meaning, and communicate emotion. As much as it is about learning facts, the talk is about learning how to look.

This is art history as it should be: open, democratic, relevant.

Copyright Disclaimer under section 107 of the Copyright Act of 1976, allowance is made for ‚Äúfair use‚Äù for purposes such as criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching, scholarship, education and research. Fair use is a use permitted by copyright statute that might otherwise be infringing.</article>

items.title: Lost Items Reveal Victorian London‚Äôs Dirty Past
items.author: History Hit
items.content:
<article>We searched the banks of the Thames for long lost historic artefacts. 

To mark the opening of the London Museum‚Äôs latest exhibition, Secrets of the Thames, History Hit's Louise Quick joined mudlark Anna Borzello on the banks of the River Thames for one of her mudlarking expeditions to search for lost artefacts.

After a morning spent scanning the banks for lost treasures, Louise heads to the exhibition to uncover the remarkable stories behind the objects recovered from the river‚Äôs muddy shores.

Secrets of the Thames: Mudlarking London‚Äôs Lost Treasures at the London Museum runs until the 1st March 2026. Tickets can be purchased in advance online or on the day, in person.

items.title: JFK's Moonshot: The Impossible Space Race Goal
items.author: Epic History
items.content:
<article>John F. Kennedy's Moonshot set the United States on a daring path to land humans on the Moon and return them safely to Earth by the end of the 1960s. In his iconic 1961 speech to Congress, Kennedy framed space conquest as a decisive Cold War challenge, arguing that the nation needed a bold, unifying goal that would accelerate science, technology, and national pride. The Moonshot galvanized NASA, industry, and universities to develop the Saturn V rocket, the Apollo Command/Service Module, and the Lunar Module, while training a generation of astronauts, engineers, and technicians. The plan demanded rapid technological advances, massive budgets, and unprecedented cross-sector coordination. Along the way, Mercury and Gemini missions built crucial experience in orbital operations, rendezvous, and life-support systems that made the Moon landings possible. In 1969, Apollo 11 achieved the primary objective: Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin walked on the lunar surface while Michael Collins orbited above, delivering humanity‚Äôs first steps beyond Earth‚Äôs gravity. The Moonshot reshaped science, engineering, education, and global prestige, triggering tech spinoffs in computing, materials, and communications that still influence modern technology. The program also faced political shifts, budget pressures, and real risks, reminding us that exploration requires courage and resilience. This video breaks down the goal, the milestones, and the enduring legacy of JFK's Moonshot. 

#JFK #MoonLanding #Apollo11 #NASA #SpaceRace #HistoryShorts #epichistory</article>

items.title: What distinguishes humans from animals? | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>What made our ancestors evolve in such an extraordinary way? This film presents the latest scientific theories on how the human species evolved and looks at the shadow side of our unique abilities.

Some animals see, hear or smell better than humans. Others can find their way in the dark much better than we can. Some can fly. All animals communicate, some have excellent memories and others build complex structures and have highly-developed social skills. 

So what sets humans apart? Why have humans evolved such highly developed cognitive abilities in comparison to animals? The documentary sheds light on this major question of human evolution -- one of the mysteries that has long puzzled the world of science.  What is it that makes humans so fundamentally different from other animal species?  And will our extraordinary abilities ultimately lead us to self-destruction?

items.author: GOTO Conferences
items.content:
<article>This interview was recorded for GOTO State of the Art in November 2025. #GOTOcon #GOTO
https://gotopia.tech

https://gotopia.tech/articles/425

https://youtu.be/Cx_vijTm24w
https://youtu.be/4HMRFcg6nEY
https://youtu.be/EGSMP2UodKM

DESCRIPTION
In this State of the Art episode, Charles Humble speaks with Adrian Mouat, Developer Relations at Chainguard and author of "Using Docker", about the evolution of container security and the persistent challenge of outdated packages.

Adrian explains how traditional Linux distributions weren't designed for the immutable, frequently-replaced nature of containers, leading to security vulnerabilities that scanners detect but teams struggle to address. He discusses how Chainguard tackles this problem by building everything from source using Wolfi, creating minimal "distroless" images with near-zero CVEs, and how concepts like SBOMs, attestations, and defense in depth are reshaping security practices.

The conversation also covers major security incidents including the XZ Utils backdoor and Shai-hulud attacks, emphasizing the importance of building from source, using short-lived credentials, and replacing rather than updating containers ‚Äì practices pioneered by companies like Google that are gradually spreading across the industry.

01:02 Early adoption of containers
02:12 The problem of outdated packages

14:39 Wolfi & building from source
20:14 Software Bill of Materials (SBOM) & attestations
27:01 Defense in depth & best practices
34:32 The XZ utils backdoor
38:14 Resources
38:52 Outro

items.title: The Kiel Canal: The busiest artificial waterway in the world | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>A technical masterpiece -- and a big responsibility. The Kiel Canal in Germany is the busiest artificial waterway in the world. But keeping it operational is expensive.

The infrastructure of the Kiel Canal is a much-discussed topic. As is the case in Germany with roads, bridges and railway tracks, cost-cutting measures are also impacting waterways. 

Yet the canal offers decisive advantages for freight transport: every shipping container transported here replaces a long lorry journey. This saves fuel and improves the freight‚Äôs carbon footprint.

Every year, 25,000 to 30,000 ships pass through the artificial waterway that runs between the port cities of Kiel and Brunsb√ºttel, connecting the Baltic Sea with the North Sea. But the Kiel Canal, which opened in 1895 and is almost 100 kilometers long, requires constant monitoring and maintenance.

In the summer of 2024, one of the large lock chambers in Brunsb√ºttel had to be shut down for several months, and the canal was widened. Up to 30,000 cubic meters of soil were removed here every day to meet the increased demands of shipping traffic. 

Two young boat builders, both named Paul, have little inkling of these challenges. They bought an old sailing boat and made it seaworthy again. The canal and its locks are the first big adventure of their journey, which will take them to the Canary Islands.

The impressive ships that sail the Kiel Canal have attracted their own fan base. Ship spotters regularly gather on the banks of the canal to watch the majestic cargo ships. 
Parking attendant Rainer Schmidt is in charge of maintenance for the Rendsburg viewing point. One of his most important tasks is to keep the hedges trimmed, to ensure the view of the canal is not obstructed.

The report highlights the different facets of the Kiel Canal and shows how closely people are connected to this waterway. It accompanies them in their everyday lives and during special challenges, against the impressive backdrop of an ageing, but fascinating, technical monument.

items.title: Opioid crisis in the US - Business & addiction (2/2) | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>Purdue Pharma earned billions with OxyContin. The company also triggered a race, as dozens of pharmaceutical companies rushed into the market. One was Insys, which sold fentanyl, a drug fifty times stronger than heroin. *Part 1: https://youtu.be/MyQQiK3vn88*

Profit was gained by any means necessary - from strippers seducing doctors to bribery, insurance fraud and massive dose increases without the consent of patients. Some did not survive.

In Florida, unscrupulous profiteers opened pain clinics that turned out to be "pill mills‚Äù - legal hubs for drugs. Chris George, head of the largest network, cynically reports on the system that made him rich before he spent 11 years in prison.

But by the end of the 2010s, the party was over: the justice system put a stop to the legal trade. Pharmacies stopped selling opioids. But the pills did not disappear. Mexican drug cartels took over the business. Members of the Sinaloa cartel explain in the documentary how they copied the methods of US pharmaceutical companies. To this day, they continue to flood the streets of America with fentanyl.

#documentary #dwdocumentary #dwdocs #opioidcrisis  #usa #addictionawareness

items.title: Venus, Cupid, Folly and Time by Agnolo Bronzino
items.author: Great Art Explained
items.content:
<article>Painted around 1545 for the Medici court in Florence, this is one of the most unsettling images of love ever made.

The painting was likely a diplomatic gift from Cosimo I de‚Äô Medici to the French court ‚Äî possibly to Francis I. That context matters. The French court loved complex allegories, intellectual puzzles, and refined eroticism. This is a painting designed to be decoded.

Unlike Renaissance harmony (think Leonardo or Raphael) this painting feels tense, airless. There is no stable ground and Venus‚Äô body twists unnaturally; Cupid‚Äôs leg bends at an impossible angle. Even beauty feels slightly disturbing.

And that‚Äôs the point.</article>

items.title: JB Pritzker wants to take down Trump | Today, Explained
items.author: Vox
items.content:
<article>Illinois Governor JB Pritzker has a playbook for fighting back against the Trump administration, and he says it‚Äôs working. Few Democratic politicians have leaned into the fight against the Trump administration as aggressively as he has. While some blue-state leaders have tried to find a lane of compromise or quiet resistance, Pritzker has gone the other direction: signing laws to limit ICE operations in Illinois, creating an accountability commission staffed by retired federal judges, suing the federal government, and successfully blocking the deployment of federalized National Guard troops on Chicago‚Äôs streets.

Pritzker is a unique figure in Democratic politics. A billionaire heir to the Hyatt hotel fortune, he has spent tens of millions of his own dollars to push for a more progressive income tax in Illinois and has advocated for a national wealth tax ‚Äî policies that would directly cost him money. He's also a Jewish Democrat who has navigated his party‚Äôs shifting positions on Israel and Gaza and is a two-term governor who has drawn some public support as a potential 2028 presidential candidate.

The February 2026 release of unredacted Epstein files is finally revealing a stark reality: while billionaire CEOs are losing their jobs overseas within hours of being unmasked, the U.S. security apparatus is still actively covering up for the "Epstein Class." items.title: Humanity in the midst of war - Survival and loss in Ukraine | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>They evacuate elderly and sick people, set up medical stations and organize escape routes. New structures of protection, security and dignity are emerging in Ukraine, while war shapes everyday life.

All of Ukraine has been at war since Russia‚Äôs full-scale attack in February 2022. It is a war whose repercussions are inescapable. And it is giving rise to new structures that every country would be happier to be able to live without. 

One of these is a network of carers who risk their lives to evacuate elderly and sick people from homes that they are often unable to leave on their own. For some, it‚Äôs the first journey of their lives, for others, the last. 

A different team, of forensic scientists and military personnel, works to identify the remains of young soldiers. The bodies of the fallen are then transported across Ukraine to their families so that they can be buried in their hometowns. These tasks are all the more difficult, as they must be accomplished amidst the constant threat of bombs and drones. 

As Russia's war of aggression rages against Ukraine, Yuri Rechinsky documents the everyday lives of those who are too weak to flee, or who care for the dead. He captures impressions of displacement, uncertainty, grief and loss, but also shows moments of solidarity, humor and resilience. "Dear Beautiful Beloved" takes a sober look at the survival strategies of people who retain their humanity in the midst of war.

#documentary #dwdocumentary #dwdocs #ukraine 
______

DW Documentary gives you knowledge beyond the headlines. Watch top documentaries from German broadcasters and international production companies. items.title: Ragnar Lothbrok death: The epic snake-pit ending and his dying words
items.author: Epic History
items.content:
<article>Ragnar Lothbrok's death in a snake pit is one of the Viking Age's most enduring legends, shaping both Norse memory and later European storytelling. Across sagas and chronicles, Ragnar's capture by Northumbria's kings and his doom at the hands of King Aelle is presented as a defining moment‚Äîan emblem of Viking fate, defiance, and the high cost of ambition. The epic scene‚ÄîRagnar hurled into a pit of venomous serpents and left to endure torture‚Äîhas been retold with varying details, but the core image remains: a royal ambush ending in a brutal ordeal that tests a warrior's courage to the limit. Equally contested are Ragnar's dying words. Different sources offer different lines, some casting him as a prophetic father warning his sons about what is to come, others giving him a stoic farewell that underscores revenge and resilience. This video traces the saga-side of the death, mapping how later storytellers and medieval chroniclers adapted the tale for their audiences, and how modern dramatizations reframe it for contemporary viewers. We compare primary sources like the Saga of Ragnar Lodbrok, the Prose Edda, and the Anglo-Saxon chronicles, noting where history ends and legend begins and how memory elevates the figure into a cultural icon. If you enjoy mythic history, epic voyages, and the way legends migrate through time, subscribe for more Viking-age legends, join the discussion about what Ragnar‚Äôs final words meant, and explore how the story informs our view of courage, kinship, and vengeance.

#RagnarLothbrok, #Vikings, #NorseMythology, #VikingHistory, #HistoryShorts, #RagnarDeath</article>

items.title: Is bigger better when it comes to muscles? | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>Muscles can do much more than just set our bodies in motion: regular muscle training has a positive impact on our overall health. This is because muscles work in a similar way to an endocrine organ: when activated, muscles release messenger substances called myokines, which directly influence our central organs such as the brain, liver, heart and intestines. If we lose muscle mass, these organs can become diseased, or metabolic disorders like diabetes can develop. Increased strength and muscle mass have been linked to better mental health, increased focus, improved sleep, and stronger immunity. 

#documentary #dwdocumentary #dwdocs #fitness

DESCRIPTION
Max Kirchoff interviews Sam Keen about his book "Clean Architecture with Python". Sam, a software developer with 30 years of experience spanning companies from startups to AWS, shares his approach to applying clean architecture principles with Python while maintaining the language's pragmatic nature.

The conversation explores the balance between architectural rigor and practical development, the critical relationship between architecture and testability, and how clean architecture principles can enhance AI-assisted coding workflows. Sam emphasizes that clean architecture isn't an all-or-nothing approach but a set of principles that developers can adapt to their context, with the core value lying in thoughtful dependency management and clear domain modeling.

items.title: Liberland: Crypto paradise or libertarian illusion? | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>Liberland is a country that doesn‚Äôt officially exist. A country that promises voluntary taxes and a lean state. It‚Äôs a libertarian utopia that‚Äôs finding more supporters worldwide.

After the Yugoslav Wars, the border between Serbia and Croatia along the Danube river remained unresolved. Vit Jedliƒçka, a former politician from the Czech Republic, took advantage of this situation. He proclaimed the "Free Republic of Liberland‚Äù on a seven-square-kilometer piece of land in 2015. 
Liberland is not internationally recognized, and its president is not allowed to set foot on the soil of his republic. Croatia sees the founding of Liberland as an attack on its territorial integrity.
The film accompanies Samuela Davidova, influencer, crypto enthusiast, and spokesperson for Liberland, and Liberland‚Äòs president, Vit Jedliƒçka, on a journey into two very different worlds. 
On the one hand, they travel to Dubai, a glittering metropolitan meeting place for crypto-enthusiastic elites. Here, they want to recruit investors ‚Äî and new citizens. 
And on the other hand, they travel to "Ark Village,‚Äù the base camp of the Liberland community on Serbian soil. Here, they celebrate the 10th anniversary of Liberland.
The highlight of the journey is a boat trip to the shores of Liberland. Liberland claims to function as a meritocracy: taxes are voluntary, but those who invest more have a greater say. 
The Liberland experiment may seem like an oddity, but it also raises serious questions: Cryptocurrencies and decentralized networks are undermining traditional national borders, and radical market ideas are gaining influence. Parallel structures are emerging. Critics see them as a threat to democracy. Others, of course, sense opportunity. 

#documentary #dwdocumentary #dwdocs #liberland #crypto #cryptocurrency 
______

items.title: 3 things that can cause painful periods - Chen X. Chen
items.author: TED-Ed
items.content:
<article>Dig into the science of what makes period cramps so painful, and find out what we still don‚Äôt know about this common experience.

--

Period pain affects hundreds of millions of people. Anywhere from 50 to 90% of people who menstruate deal with painful abdominal or pelvic cramps during their period. Individual experiences can vary, from mild discomfort, to throbbing aches, to contraction-like cramps that rival the pain of labor. So, why do menstrual cramps hurt so much? Chen X. Chen explains this surprisingly common experience.

Lesson by Chen X. Chen, directed by Caitlin McCarthy.

items.title: After Q-Day: Quantum Applications at Scale ‚Ä¢ Matthew Keesan ‚Ä¢ YOW! 2025
items.author: GOTO Conferences
items.content:
<article>This presentation was recorded at YOW! Australia 2025. #GOTOcon #YOW
https://yowcon.com

Matthew Keesan - VP & GM at IonQ

RESOURCES
https://twitter.com/keesan
https://github.com/mjk
https://www.linkedin.com/in/keesan
https://www.keesan.net

Links
https://plus.maths.org/content/hypersphere-in-4D
https://iontrap.duke.edu/2021/10/19/fault-tolerant-operation-of-a-quantum-error-correction-code
https://www.csiro.au/en/news/All/News/2025/October/Breakthrough-quantum-secure-link-protects-data-using-the-laws-of-physics
https://arxiv.org/abs/2504.08732
https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.22408
https://arxiv.org/abs/2503.13128
https://www.scottaaronson.com/democritus
https://github.com/Munich-Quantum-Software-Stack
https://openqse.org
https://unitary.foundation

ABSTRACT
In the span of one generation, quantum computers have gone from thought experiments to globally deployed commercial products on the verge of becoming a standard tool in high-performance computing (HPC).

Much early motivation in (and funding for) developing practical quantum computers resulted from Peter Shor's discovery of an efficient quantum algorithm for factorization‚Äîthereby threatening the RSA encryption standard. If today's quantum computing manufacturers achieve their roadmaps, RSA-2048 will be broken within the next few years. Beyond a sea change for encrypted communications globally, this heralds the arrival of a new era of HPC workflows and the possibility of solving heretofore unsolvable problems.

In this talk, we will discuss the current state of research into what applications might come online first, the nascent ecosystems for delivering them, and the call to action to all developers to prepare for Q-Day and beyond! [...]

items.title: Al-Zawahiri - The 911 Mastermind Who Nearly Escaped (Full Documentary)
items.author: The People Profiles
items.content:
<article>Who was the real power behind the world's most notorious terror network? While Osama bin Laden was the face of Al-Qaeda, many intelligence experts argue that Ayman al-Zawahiri was the true operational mastermind and strategic architect of the 9/11 attacks.

In this deep-dive documentary, we explore the chilling transformation of an Egyptian surgeon into the world‚Äôs most wanted man. We uncover how Ayman al-Zawahiri radicalized Bin Laden, merging his Egyptian Islamic Jihad group with Al-Qaeda to create a global insurgency. For over two decades, the CIA manhunt for "The Doctor" spanned continents, from the mountains of Tora Bora to his final days in a Kabul safehouse.

We break down the high-stakes counter-terrorism operation that ended with a precision drone strike on a balcony in Afghanistan. Was Zawahiri more dangerous than Bin Laden? How did he manage to evade justice for 21 years? Join us as we examine the legacy of the man who redefined modern warfare and the War on Terror.

items.title: A Custom Panoramic Pentax 645 (Half-Frame Medium Format)
items.author: Kyle McDougall
items.content:
<article>Head to https://squarespace.com/kylemcdougall to save 10% off your first purchase of a website or domain using code KYLEMCDOUGALL

In this video, I'm out shooting with a very unique camera‚Äîa custom modified Pentax 645 that shoots half-frame medium-format film, exposing 33 images on a roll of 120. This was lent to me by a viewer of the channel, who figured out a way to modify the camera to essentially shoot the XPAN frame size. 

I head out and shoot in my local area, as well as on the English coast, sharing the experience, and later wrap things up with some thoughts about frame size and how the camera was modified.

items.title: Martinique: The deadliest volcanic eruption of the 20th century | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>There are around 1,500 known active volcanoes worldwide. A volcano is considered active if it has erupted in the last 10,000 years. Around 40 to 60 volcanoes erupt every year.

The eruption of Mont Pel√©e on the Caribbean island of Martinique is considered the deadliest volcanic eruption of the 20th century. 
On May 8, 1902, a pyroclastic flow wiped out the island's  cultural capital, Saint-Pierre. Known as the "Paris of the Caribbean,‚Äù the city was located just seven kilometers away from the eruption, and was engulfed in a matter of minutes. An estimated 28,000 to 30,000 people were killed - they were burned, or suffocated. 
The eruption came as a complete surprise to the islanders, as the signs of the volcano‚Äôs activity were ignored. 
The disaster led to the establishment of the first volcanic observatories and marked the birth of volcanology. 

#documentary #dwdocumentary #dwdocs #martinique #volcano 
______

items.title: This Swedish Hotel Is Made of 30K Tons of Ice and Snow
items.author: The Wall Street Journal
items.content:
<article>Nearly 100 workers race to Jukkasjarvi, Sweden, each November to build the world-renowned Icehotel. They have only weeks to create the entire structure and all the rooms before mid-December, and the materials pose some unique logistical challenges. The hotel includes a main hall, a ceremony hall for weddings and 12 suites custom-made by artists from around the world.

WSJ traveled to Sweden to see the steps and the challenges of how this hotel is made every year from 30,000 tons of ice and snow.

#Hotels #Travel #WSJ</article>

items.title: Crisis in Venezuela: An Uncertain Future (full documentary) | FRONTLINE (PBS)
items.author: FRONTLINE PBS | Official
items.content:
<article>What comes next for Venezuela after the Trump administration‚Äôs dramatic capture of Nicol√°s Maduro?

This journalism is made possible by viewers like you. Donate to FRONTLINE now: https://bit.ly/47DFzCb

And support your local PBS station here: https://www.pbs.org/donate

In ‚ÄúCrisis in Venezuela,‚Äù FRONTLINE and The Associated Press investigate President Trump‚Äôs long campaign to topple Maduro, the legacy of corruption in Venezuela, the challenges to democracy and the fight over who will control the oil-rich South American country.

The documentary probes Venezuela‚Äôs uncertain future and the Maduro regime insiders who‚Äôve been left in charge while opposition leader Mar√≠a Corina Machado remains in exile. Those insiders include Venezuela‚Äôs acting president Delcy Rodr√≠guez ‚Äî who, the AP found, has been on the radar of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration for years.

It also examines the Trump administration‚Äôs relationship with Rodr√≠guez and its approach to democracy in Venezuela in the aftermath of Maduro‚Äôs capture. 

‚ÄúCrisis in Venezuela‚Äù is a FRONTLINE production with Mongoose Pictures and Documento Films in association with The Associated Press. The reporters are Joshua Goodman and Regina Garc√≠a Cano. The writers are Jeff Arak & Juan Ravell. The producer is Jeff Arak. The director is Juan Ravell. The senior producers are Dan Edge and Eamonn Matthews. The managing editor of FRONTLINE is Andrew Metz. The editor-in-chief and executive producer of FRONTLINE is Raney Aronson-Rath.

Explore additional reporting on ‚ÄúCrisis in Venezuela‚Äù on our website: https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/documentary/crisis-in-venezuela/

items.title: FBI Releases Video of Masked Person in Nancy Guthrie Investigation
items.author: The Wall Street Journal
items.content:
<article>The FBI shared footage of an armed individual appearing to tamper with Nancy Guthrie's camera on the morning of her disappearance.‚Å†
‚Å†
Guthrie, 84 years old, is the mother of ‚ÄúToday‚Äù co-anchor Savannah Guthrie, and her sudden disappearance has made national headlines. Nancy Guthrie was first reported missing on Feb. 1 and authorities are investigating her disappearance as a crime.‚Å†

items.title: The turbulent life of Gaddafi's son: On the death of Saif al-Islam Gaddafi | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>On 3 February 2026, Saif al-Islam Gaddafi was shot dead by four unknown gunmen in Zintan, Libya. This documentary was produced in 2023 and has not been updated for this reupload. It traces the turbulent life of the second son of the former Libyan dictator Muammar al-Gaddafi. In 2021, Saif al-Islam Gaddafi unexpectedly announced that he would run for the presidency in Libya.

Statements from relatives and political actors paint a portrait of an unpredictable and fiercely determined man. Saif al-Islam Gaddafi‚Äôs presidential bid is a major challenge for Libya. The second son of the Libyan dictator Muammar Al Gaddafi has been convicted several times in Libya and is being prosecuted by the International Criminal Court for crimes against humanity.

Saif al-Islam Gaddafi has had an unusual life: he grew up a clan that operated with a high degree of paranoia, suspecting conspiracies at work everwhere. Later, he led a playboy lifestyle in Europe, presenting himself to the world as a reformer. In the second phase of his life, which began with the Libyan revolution of 2011, he perpetuated the repressive style of his father‚Äôs regime. He was taken prisoner by anti-Gaddafi militias who made him stand trial -- but only allowed him to take part via videolink. 

Everyone in Libya is talking about him, all kinds of rumors are doing the rounds, his life is under threat. People say he‚Äôs a crazy, sick mystic who‚Äôs absconded into the desert. What‚Äôs making him run for president, despite the death threats? Does he stand a chance of winning? What does he know about the secret machinations of his father‚Äôs regime? His eventful life mirrors the current chaos in Libya: a country divided, with one government in the east and another in the west, rival militias vying for power and foreign states influencing the conflict. With statements from relatives and political actors, the film paints a portrait of Saif al-Islam Gaddafi - an unpredictable and fiercely determined survivor who is trying to find his way.  

#documentary #dwdocumentary #dwdocs #libya #gaddafi 
______

items.title: Napoleon's Genius at Austerlitz vs. Trafalgar Disaster
items.author: Epic History
items.content:
<article>In 1805, during the Napoleonic Wars, two pivotal battles highlighted the highs and lows of Napoleon Bonaparte's empire-building. First, his brilliance shone at the Battle of Austerlitz on December 2, dubbed the "Battle of the Three Emperors." Facing a larger Austro-Russian army of 85,000 under Tsar Alexander I and Emperor Francis II, Napoleon's 68,000 French troops executed a masterful strategy. He deliberately weakened his right flank to lure the allies into a trap, then launched a devastating counterattack on the Pratzen Heights, splitting their forces. Using fog for cover and precise artillery, Napoleon's Grande Arm√©e inflicted 16,000 casualties while losing only 9,000. The victory dissolved the Third Coalition, forced Austria to sue for peace, and cemented Napoleon's reputation as a tactical genius, leading to the Confederation of the Rhine and his continental dominance.

Conversely, Trafalgar's tragedy unfolded at sea on October 21, off Spain's Cape Trafalgar. Napoleon's invasion plans for Britain hinged on naval superiority, but Admiral Pierre-Charles Villeneuve's combined Franco-Spanish fleet of 33 ships met British Admiral Horatio Nelson's 27 vessels. Nelson's innovative "breaking the line" tactic divided the enemy formation, resulting in a crushing defeat: 22 allied ships captured or destroyed, with no British losses. Nelson died from wounds, but the battle ensured British naval supremacy, ending Napoleon's dreams of invading England and shifting his focus to land campaigns. These battles encapsulate Napoleon's land genius versus his naval vulnerabilities, reshaping Europe's power balance.

#napoleon #napoleonicwars #navalhistory #epichistory #epichistorytv</article>

items.title: LGBTQ+ resistance to Orb√°n | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>The mayor of Budapest, Gergely Kar√°csony, is facing criminal charges. In defiance of President Viktor Orb√°n‚Äôs ban, he organized a Pride march in the city on 28 June 2025‚Äîthe largest such event ever held in Hungary.

A few months earlier, the government had further tightened its controversial so-called Child Protection Law, which severely restricts the rights of the LGBTQ+ community in Hungary. The Pride event drew supporters both from within the country and abroad. 

Our documentary follows B√©la, Zsu, and Norbert, who refuse to be intimidated and are prepared to publicly stand up against Orb√°n‚Äôs authoritarian government.

Photographer B√©la Varadi is Roma and identifies as queer. He moved to London a few years after the right-wing nationalist Fidesz party came to power in 2010, making life increasingly hard for queer people and minorities. B√©la visited Hungary in 2025 to take photos at the Pride march.
In Budapest, B√©la meets up with Norbert, who is also Roma and queer. Norbert loves the city, but social tensions are proving challenging. Despite support from his family, Norbert is considering emigrating‚Äîa step many queer people in Hungary have already taken.

Zsu and Enik≈ë are a young lesbian couple from Budapest. They recently bought a house in the countryside and plan to move there soon. But how will they fare as outsiders in a rural community?

#documentary #dwdocumentary #dwdocs #LGBTQ+ #hungary 
______

items.title: The machine that changed our understanding of human history - Max G. Levy
items.author: TED-Ed
items.content:
<article>Learn more at https://brilliant.org/TedEd

--

In 1900, Greek divers stumbled upon a 2,000-year-old shipwreck whose contents would shake our understanding of the ancient world. Among the remains were fragments of mangled wood and corroded metal, which archaeologists soon realized were parts of the oldest geared device ever discovered ‚Äî and humankind‚Äôs first computer. So, how did it work? Max G. Levy explains the Antikythera mechanism.

DESCRIPTION
Roman Zhukov (Red Hat) and Damian Brady (GitHub) explore the evolving landscape of AI-assisted software development. They discuss how AI tools are transforming developer workflows, making developers about 20% faster on simple tasks while being 19% slower on complex ones.

The conversation covers critical topics including code quality and trust, security concerns with AI-generated code, the importance of education and best practices, and how developer roles are shifting from syntax experts to system architects. Both experts emphasize that AI tools serve as amplifiers rather than replacements, with humans remaining essential in the loop for quality, security, and licensing compliance.

Called the Lapua movement, it was a far-right group of Finns who sought to overthrow the republic, marginalize communists, and install an authoritarian government. But then‚Ä¶something happened. Almost overnight, the Lapua movement collapsed. And democracy in Finland has been stable ever since.

items.title: Creating Momentum with The Value Flywheel Effect ‚Ä¢ David Anderson ‚Ä¢ GOTO 2025
items.author: GOTO Conferences
items.content:
<article>This presentation was recorded at GOTO Serverless 2025. #GOTOcon #GOTOserverless
https://conferences.gotopia.tech/goto-serverless-bengaluru-2025

David Anderson - Software Architect at G-P/Globalization Partners & Author of "The Value Flywheel Effect"

RESOURCES
https://twitter.com/davidand393
https://www.linkedin.com/in/david-anderson-belfast
https://theserverlessedge.com

Links
https://www.eventcatalog.dev

ABSTRACT
Technology strategy is complicated, and disruption is a constant. How do you know that the path you are on will work out - you don‚Äôt. Are you struggling with complexity, inertia and problems? It‚Äôs time to stop spinning your wheels and start building real momentum. Join David Anderson, author of The Value Flywheel Effect, for a session dedicated to breaking this cycle. He will share tried-and-tested mechanisms to build a self-reinforcing engine for innovation, accelerating value delivery. The Value Flywheel Effect is a proven framework that empowers teams to achieve accelerating cycles of learning, delivery, and value through focused modernization.

In this talk, you'll learn:
‚Ä¢ Creating Flow: Modernization is about movement. The balance between solid foundations and rapid progress is important.

‚Ä¢ Keep it Simple: Learn how leveraging standards for technology, architecture, patterns, and practices creates safety.

‚Ä¢ The Right Tech: Explore how combining cloud infrastructure, architecture, services, and techniques can eliminate undifferentiated heavy lifting.

Drawing on real-world experiences, this session will equip technology leaders with the insights to shape a robust strategy. The ultimate goal is to foster readiness for future challenges. We'll demonstrate how the momentum you cultivate today will enable you to harness tomorrow's technologies. [...]

items.title: The problem with gamifying life | The Gray Area
items.author: Vox
items.content:
<article>Games are fun. Aren‚Äôt they?

Subscribe to our channel! http://goo.gl/0bsAjO

When we play games ‚Äî board games, video games, any kind of game ‚Äî something magical happens. Games allow us to explore, to create little worlds where we can be different versions of ourselves. But when we turn life into a game ‚Äî where we have to get the best grade, or the most money, or the most ‚Äúlikes‚Äù ‚Äî then games stop being fun. Why is that?

This week Sean speaks with philosopher C. Thi Nguyen about what a game really is, the difference between playing for enjoyment and playing to win, and why games lose their magic when the stakes become real.

Thi argues that the things we value in life are increasingly captured by grades and likes and downloads and step counts and a thousand other metrics that quietly rewrite what we want and what we think makes us happy.

Host: Sean Illing (@SeanIlling)
Guest: C. Thi Nguyen, author of The Score

00:00 Intro

24:26 Metrics and ‚Äúvalue capture‚Äù

items.title: Strong women - The fight for self-determination | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>Women around the world are working to break down outdated structures and empower one another. Initiatives in Germany and Ecuador are calling for equal rights in the workplace, self-determination, and financial independence for women.

One of the women working for change is surgeon Katja Schlosser. The former head physician at Agaplesion Hospital in Giessen is working with her association "Die Chirurginnen‚Äù (The Female Surgeons) to ensure that female colleagues can continue to practice their profession even during pregnancy. In some clinics, pregnant women are still banned from operating rooms - often due to restrictive interpretations of the Maternity Protection Act. This can put female surgeons at a disadvantage compared to their male colleagues. That‚Äôs why Katja Schlosser is calling for an equal say in decision-making processes, as well as equal career opportunities for women.
Standing up for themselves is often difficult for girls from male-dominated cultures. Take Bahareh Husseini. She fled Iran and now lives in the German city of D√ºsseldorf. She wanted to study and be able determine her own path in life. In Germany, she found support at Diakonie, a Protestant social welfare organization. There, Jessica te Heesen heads the JUMP project, which helps refugee girls develop self-confidence, assert themselves, and find their way in school and at work. Bahareh is now studying medical physics ‚Äî and passing on her experiences to others. 
This is exactly what Patricia Yaselga is promoting with her SEDAL foundation in Ecuador. In the north of the country, many indigenous women have little choice but to work in the cut flower industry. It usually pays only the minimum wage and contaminates the once fertile soil with pesticides and artificial fertilizers. Among the consequences: poverty and malnutrition. SEDAL offers workshops in organic farming for indigenous women so that they can become financially independent and feed their families. The courses don‚Äôt just teach them cultivation techniques, but also how to develop self-confidence and assert their rights. Some of the organic farmers are now also politically active in their communities.

items.title: This Swedish Hotel Is Made of 30K Tons of Ice and Snow
items.author: The Wall Street Journal
items.content:
<article>Nearly 100 workers race to Jukkasjarvi, Sweden, each November to build the world-renowned Icehotel. They have only weeks to create the entire structure and all the rooms before mid-December, and the materials pose some unique logistical challenges. The hotel includes a main hall, a ceremony hall for weddings and 12 suites custom-made by artists from around the world.

WSJ traveled to Sweden to see the steps and the challenges of how this hotel is made every year from 30,000 tons of ice and snow.

items.title: Buster Keaton - The Man Who Risked Everything for a Laugh Documentary
items.author: The People Profiles
items.content:
<article>Discover the legendary life and career of Buster Keaton, the "Great Stone Face" of silent film. In this deep dive, we explore why Buster Keaton remains one of the most influential figures in cinema history, famously performing the most dangerous stunts ever captured on film without the help of CGI or safety nets. From the iconic house-falling scene in Steamboat Bill, Jr. to the massive scale of The General, Keaton redefined physical comedy and visual storytelling.

We examine the Buster Keaton legacy, tracing his journey from Vaudeville prodigy to Hollywood icon and his eventual rediscovery as a master of cinematic technique. We break down his unique approach to action comedy, his rivalry with Charlie Chaplin, and the tragic story of his struggle for creative control during the transition to talkies.

Whether you are a lifelong fan of silent movies or a newcomer curious about the genius of Buster Keaton, this video reveals the real-life stunts and brilliant mind of a man who literally risked his life for a laugh. items.title: Opioid crisis in the US - Business & addiction (1/2) | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>The United States has a huge drug problem: cheap opioids, thousands of deaths. President Trump blames Latin American cartels. But it all began 30 years ago, quite legally, in the United States.

The Sackler family, owners of Purdue Pharma, brought the prescription painkiller OxyContin - containing the highly potent opioid oxycodone - onto the market, unleashing one of the greatest health disasters in the history of the United States. With hundreds of sales representatives, they pressured doctors in economically disadvantaged regions to prescribe the drug. 

One of the film's protagonists is Dr Lou Ortenzio, who was himself part of this machinery: he brought the drug to his town of Clarksburg before becoming addicted himself. Former sales representatives, now whistleblowers, report how they lied to doctors and claimed that Oxy was not addictive.

A perfectly oiled machine got millions of Americans hooked - and deceived an entire country. Prosecutors like Maura Healey describe their fight to stop Purdue and bring the Sacklers to justice. The investigations reveal a network of power and influence: Purdue secretly received support from McKinsey, consulting firm to the powerful, and from Publicis, a major advertising agency.

Through exclusive interviews, insider accounts and previously unpublished archive material, this two-part documentary reveals how the Sacklers bribed regulators, pushed Oxy and evaded justice despite overwhelming evidence. The two-part documentary tells the story of a crisis that continues to devastate parts of American society to this day.

*[Part 2 coming next week]*

items.title: WWII Codebreakers: Cracking Enigma and the Ultra Secret
items.author: Epic History
items.content:
<article>During World War II, the Enigma machine was a portable encryption device used by Nazi Germany to secure military communications. Invented in the 1920s by Arthur Scherbius, it resembled a typewriter with rotors, plugs, and lamps that scrambled messages into unbreakable codes‚Äî or so the Germans thought. Each key press rotated the rotors, creating billions of possible settings, making decryption seem impossible without the daily key.

Enter the Allied codebreakers at Bletchley Park, Britain‚Äîa secret hub of mathematicians, linguists, and engineers. Led by figures like Alan Turing, they formed the Government Code and Cypher School (GC&CS). Polish cryptologists had cracked early Enigma versions in the 1930s, sharing insights with the Allies before Poland's invasion.

Turing and his team built the "Bombe," an electromechanical machine that tested Enigma settings at high speed, exploiting flaws like repeated message keys. By 1940, they routinely broke codes, producing intelligence codenamed "Ultra." This ultra-secret info, from intercepted German signals, revealed troop movements, U-boat positions, and battle plans.

Ultra's impact was immense: it shortened the war by up to two years, aiding D-Day and the Battle of the Atlantic. Codebreakers like Joan Clarke and Gordon Welchman worked in huts, under immense pressure, sworn to secrecy‚Äîeven postwar. Their efforts saved millions of lives but came at personal costs, including Turing's tragic fate. Today, Enigma symbolizes the dawn of modern computing and cybersecurity.

#EpicHistoryTV #EpicHistory #History #WW2 #WW2history #WorldWar2</article>

items.title: A rare look inside Russia‚Äôs prisons | DW Documentary
items.author: DW Documentary
items.content:
<article>The Gulag was a vast system of forced labor camps in the Soviet Union, where prisoners, including political detainees, were subjected to harsh conditions, hard labor, and widespread abuses. Anna Karetnikova, a former senior analyst at Russia‚Äôs Penitentiary Service, says today‚Äôs prison system has only seen limited reform since then and raises concerns about conditions, violence and a lack of legal protections. 

In recent years, human rights groups and international observers have documented severe conditions in Russian prisons, including overcrowding and arbitrary punishment, and have raised concerns about political imprisonment. Many individuals have been convicted under Putin‚Äôs broad ‚Äúextremism‚Äù and ‚Äúterrorism‚Äù laws.

items.title: Jasmine Crockett isn‚Äôt backing down | Today, Explained
items.author: Vox
items.content:
<article>Rep. Jasmine Crockett wants you to know she comes by her controversies and clap-backs honestly. The representative from Texas has served just two terms in Congress, but is already a rising political star and a bona fide internet sensation. She‚Äôs also become a political lightning rod for Democrats as well as Republicans. Crockett has built her brand on coining phrases that are almost President Donald Trump-like in their virality. She goes after the president and the administration relentlessly, and says it's the only way to stay relevant and gain voters‚Äô trust in the Trump era.

But if Democrats are less than thrilled with her performance, that‚Äôs due more to style than substance, at least, according to her. This week on Today, Explained, Vox‚Äôs Astead Herndon travels to Washington, DC, to meet with Crockett and finds her unwilling to back down from her most controversial statements, including comments about some Latino voters having a ‚Äúslave mentality‚Äù and that she doesn‚Äôt need Trump voters to win.

Regret and apology are not Crockett‚Äôs brand, which has many Democrats worrying about her candidacy for a Senate seat in Texas. In this interview, she walks through her plan and formula for winning that Senate seat: running up the numbers among Black voters, the most loyal voting block for Democrats in Texas, and encouraging nonvoters to participate in the primary.

00:17 Intro 
01:25 Who is a Jasmine Crockett voter?
01:59 The ‚Äòbleach blonde‚Äô moment: planned or not?
03:20 Are clapbacks the new Democratic strategy?
05:28 From public defender to Congress
07:38 Strategy for Democrats to win 
11:41 Race and racism in US politics
14:12 Viral anti-Rep. Crockett moments in culture
17:52 Policy pushbacks against Rep. Crockett

items.title: The House of Representatives is stuck at 435 seats. That‚Äôs a problem. #shorts
items.author: Vox
items.content:
<article>For more than a century, the size of the House of Representatives has been frozen at 435 seats ‚Äî and in that same period, the US population has tripled. This means that today, the average representative is responsible for more than 750,000 constituents. Scholars and politicians argue this imbalance helps explain why many Americans feel disconnected from Congress. 

Rep. Sean Casten (D-IL) has introduced a bill that would expand the House, aiming to restore a vision closer to what the founders intended: a House that expanded with the population. Supporters say more seats could improve representation, but the idea raises a key question: Would a larger House function better ‚Äî or just add to the gridlock? Vox explores the math, history, and future of a ‚Äúbigger‚Äù American democracy.
